items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling slowly on the River Pang. However, flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible, especially in areas close to the river around Tidmarsh due to high groundwater levels. The beginning of the week is expected to be mainly dry, with some bands of rain and isolated showers possible towards the end of the week. We expect river levels to continue to gradually fall, but levels will be sensitive to rainfall. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
This Alert is issued for the high tide at 4:45 PM on Sunday 30th March.

High spring tides accompanied by strong winds and waves mean flooding is possible around the high tide between 3:45 PM on 30/03/2025 and 5:45 PM on Sunday 30/03/2025.

Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths.

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this Alert for any subsequent tides if required.

This message will be updated by 7:00 PM on Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 9:45pm and 11:45pm today, Sunday 30th March. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.78mAODN at 10:45pm, on Sunday 30th March, which is 0.53m above tide tables, wind force 4, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am, Monday 31st March.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight, between 12:45am and 2:45am on Monday 31st March. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50mAODN at 1:45am, on Monday 31st March, which is 0.3m above tide tables, wind force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am, Monday 31st March.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 3pm and 6pm today,  Sunday 30/03/2025. 

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and the tidal River Esk. 

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9:00pm Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight, between 12:45am and 2:45am on Monday 31st March. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50mAODN at 1:45am, on Monday 31st March, which is 0.3m above tide tables, wind force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am, Monday 31st March.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.90 mAOD at 16:30 on 30/03/25 and 4.80 mAOD at 04:00 on 31/03/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 53 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 31/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light Northerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 6.32 metres Chart Datum (3.27 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday afternoon's tide at 13:30 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be 38 cm lower (2.89 mAOD). Flood impacts could return again on Tuesday 1st April. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 31/03/2025.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 5pm and 7pm today, Sunday 30/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9:00pm Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Thorney Island to West Itchenor
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 31/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light North Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.21 m. The total forecast tide is 5.40 metres Chart Datum (2.66 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, flooding will affect a small number of properties in Bosham High Street. Water will be high up slipways in West Itchenor. Gardens or land of shoreside properties around Chichester Harbour will also be affected. Monday afternoon's tide at 13:45 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be 40 cm lower (2.26 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected Monday afternoon, or through next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 18:00 on 31/03/2025.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 31/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light Northerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 6.32 metres Chart Datum (3.27 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, water will be high up slipways and drains, which might cause minor flooding to roads. If the tide comes in a little higher than we are predicting, the tide could be close to the top of the river bank in some locations, and it could be possible for a small amount of water to affect boat yards. Monday afternoon's tide at 13:30 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be 38 cm lower (2.89 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected Monday afternoon, or through next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 31/03/2025.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday morning.  High water at Plymouth is at 07:57 am, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.72 mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to vary only slightly due to calm conditions and high pressure. 
 
 
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas including Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park at Fowey, Quay Street and Recreation ground at Lostwithiel, Polperro Harbour, Quay Road and The Quay at Looe and the B3247 at Seaton 
 
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   
  
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information if the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday morning.  High water at Falmouth is at 07.23 am, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.74 mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to vary only slightly due to calm conditions and high pressure. 
 
Locations particularly at risk include low lying coastal communities including Cadgwith and Coverack, Porthallow, the tidal Helford Estuary, Maenporth and Swanpool, St.Mawes, East Portholland, Gorran Haven,  Portmellon, Mevagissey, Pentewan and Par 
 
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   


We are monitoring the situation and will update this information if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible for a few hours either side of high water at 7:30 PM on 29/03/2025 and 8:45 AM om 30/03/2025
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We have closed flood gates at Pill.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 7:30 PM on 29/03/2025 with a level of 7.53 mAODN with south-westerly force 4 winds.  The second forecast tide is at 8:45 AM on 30/03/2025 with a level of 7.68mAOD with westerly force 4 winds.  This Flood Alert is likely to be in force until Tuesday 1st April.
This message will be updated in the afternoon of 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding remains possible for this afternoons high tide, Sunday 30th March, and tomorrow mornings high tide, Monday 31st March. High water at Ilfracombe is at 19:45 BST this afternoon and 08:15 BST tomorrow morning, times of high water will vary along the coast.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 31/03/2025.

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:30 BST on 31/03/2025, at  the following locations: 

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 02:00 BST 

Eastford Rd, peaking around 02:30 BST

Arpley, peaking around 02:45 BST 

Howley, peaking around 02:45 BST

Knutsford Rd, peaking around 02:45 BST

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities

This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides are expected from Sunday 30th March through to Wednesday 2nd April which may cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast. 

This flood alert covers the high tide between 00:00 BST on 31/03/2025 and 02:00 BST on 31/03/2025, with the highest tide level expected around 01:00 BST. This flood alert is also covers the lunchtime tide, with the highest level expected around 13:30 BST 31/03/2025.

Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

This message will be updated by 5PM on 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth
items.message:
High tides are expected from Sunday 30th March through to Wednesday 2nd April which may cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast. 

The overnight tide between 00:00 BST on 30/03/2025 and 02:00 BST on 30/03/2025, does not reach flood alert.  However the alert is being left in place for for tomorrows lunchtime tide, with the highest level expected around 13:30 BST 31/03/2025.

Areas most at risk include Coastline from Gretna to Silloth.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

This message will be updated by 10AM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides from 31 March 2025 may lead to flooding. This flood alert covers the high tide at 13:15 BST on 31/03/2025 with further detail as follows;

Date of FA Threshold being met : 31/03/2025
Time of FA Threshold being met : 12:45 BST
Duration of FA Threshold being exceeded: 15 mins 
Peak Water Level: 5.40mAOD
Time of Peak Water Level: 13:15- 13:30 BST
Time of High Astronomical Tide (tide table): 13:24 BST
High Astronomical Tide Level (tide table): 5.33mAOD
Wind Direction: SW
Wind Speed: Force 2


Subsequent high tides up to and including the mid day high tide on 01/04/2025 are expected to reach the Flood Alert level.  This message will be updated by 8:00AM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides from 31 March 2025 may cause flooding. This alert covers the high tide at 12:45BST on 31/03/2025 with further details as follows;

Date of FA Threshold being met : 31/03/2025
Time of FA Threshold being met : 12:45 BST
Duration of FA Threshold being exceeded: 15 mins 
Peak Water Level: 5.65mAOD
Time of Peak Water Level: 13:15 BST
Time of High Astronomical Tide (tide table): 13:24 BST
High Astronomical Tide Level (tide table): 5.33mAOD
Wind Direction: SW
Wind Speed: Force 2

The thresholds set at Glasson Dock are not forecast to be reached in this set of Spring Tides. The maximum level forecast to be reached is 5.68mAOD at 13:30 BST on 31/03/25. This message will be updated by 8:00AM on 31/03/25 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:45pm and 8:45pm today, Sunday 30th March. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches, and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells, and Blakeney. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Wells of 3.99 mAODN at 7:45pm, on Sunday 30th March, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 31st March.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message:
High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding between 4:30 PM and 8:30PM today, Sunday 30/03/2025. 

Flooding is expected to affect areas on Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9:00PM Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 4.30pm and 9pm today, Sunday 30/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9pm Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 5.30pm and 9.30pm today, Sunday 30/03/2025, and again tomorrow, Monday 31/03/2025 between 7pm and 9.30pm. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point, including Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. Further flooding is possible over the next few days due to high spring tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9:00PM Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high spring tides are expected for 3 days. Commencing with the high tide on Sunday morning 30/03/2025, flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary.
Predicted peaks. Sharpness 10.0m to 10.2m at 21:45 on 30/03/2025 and 10.2m to 10.4m at 10:00 on 31/03/2025.
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
This Alert is issued for the high tide at 4:45 PM on Sunday 30th March.

High spring tides accompanied by strong winds and waves mean flooding is possible at Newcastle Quayside around the high tide between 3:45 PM on 30/03/2025 and 5:45 PM on Sunday 30/03/2025.

Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths with the potential for some minor overtopping near the Swing Bridge at Newcastle Quayside  We are working closely with Newcastle City Council to ensure that any sandbagging requirements are in place.  

We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this Alert for any subsequent tides if required.

Detailed tidal information for those that use it; The forecast high tide level is 3.40mAOD.

This message will be updated by 7:00 PM on Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
This Alert is issued for the high tide at 4:45 PM on Sunday 30th March.

High spring tides accompanied by strong winds and waves mean flooding is possible around the high tide between 3:45 PM on 30/03/2025 and 5:45 PM on Sunday 30/03/2025.

Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths around Alnmouth. 

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

There are currently no plans to close the Flood Gates at Warkworth. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this Alert for any subsequent tides if required.

This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 31/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light Northerly Force 3 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 5.20 metres Chart Datum (2.47 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Impacts will be relatively minor and confined to the immediate sea front. For 30 minutes either side of high tide, water will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, but flood depths will be relatively shallow. Monday afternoon's tide at 13:30 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be 32 cm lower (2.15 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 12:00 on 31/03/2025.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday morning. High water at St Ives is at 7:15am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at St Ives is 3.86 mAOD, with a surge of 0.180m above astronomical tide level.
Possible wave overtopping could occur within St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the causeway at Hayle.
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   
 
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information if the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight between 12:30am and 2:30am on Monday 31st March. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may experience some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.01mAODN at 1:30am, on Monday 31st March, which is 0.37m above tide tables, wind force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am, Monday 31st March.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade at 8:45 AM on 30/03/2025. Flooding is possible for an hour either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.77 mAODN at 8:45 AM on 30/03/2025, which is 0.08 m above tide tables, with westerly force 4 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level.
There may be further tides that require this flood alert.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.
All times are British Summer Time.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: High spring tides combined with a tidal surge will result in higher tide levels than usual between 19:45 and 21:45 this evening, 30/03/2025. Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 5.32mAODN at 19:45 on Sunday 30 March, which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Monday at 08:45am is currently forecast to below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10.30pm this evening, Sunday 30 March.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: High spring tides combined with a tidal surge will result in higher tide levels than usual between 19:45 and 21:45 this evening, 30/03/2025. Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.32mAODN at 19:45 on Sunday 30 March, which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Monday at 08:45am is currently forecast to below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10.30pm this evening, Sunday 30 March.

items.description: King's Lynn, West Lynn and The Wash frontage in Norfolk
items.message: High spring tides combined with a tidal surge will result in higher tide levels than usual between 19:45 and 21:45 this evening, 30/03/2025. Areas most at risk are King's Lynn, West Lynn, Clenchwarton, Terrington St Clement, Walpole Cross Keys and Tilney All Saints. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.32mAODN at 19:45 on Sunday 30 March, which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). South quay will be closed to traffic from 17:00hrs today. The following tide on Monday at 08:45am is currently forecast to below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10.30pm this evening, Sunday 30 March.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse, Don and the Dutch River catchment

floodArea.county: Doncaster, East Riding of Yorkshire, North Lincolnshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, River Don, Dutch River

items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this afternoon and into the evening may lead to flooding.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible from 8:00 PM on 30/03/2025.
Areas most at risk include the south bank of the River Ouse from Airmyn to Whitgift and the River Don and Dutch River from Thorne to Goole.
After the high tide this evening, the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high spring tides are expected over 3 days. Commencing with the high tide on Saturday morning, flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow.
Predicted peaks: Newport 7.2m to 7.4m at 21:00 on 30/03/2025 and 7.4m to 7.6m at 09:15 on 31/03/2025.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.6m to 7.8m at 21:00 on 30/03/2025 and 7.9m to 8.1m at 09:30 on 31/03/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Camel Estuary at Rock and low lying properties on the Little Petherick Creek
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Cornwall Coast, Tidal Camel Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday morning. High water at Padstow is at 7:25am. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Padstow is 4.38 mAOD, with a surge of 0.07m above astronomical tide level.
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   
 
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information if the situation changes.

items.message:
A flood warning has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over 3 days. Commencing with the high tide on Saturday evening, the 29/03/2025. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. High Tides may impact properties and roads including garages at Brockweir.
Predicted peaks: Newport 7.2m to 7.4m at 21:00 on 30/03/2025 and 7.4m to 7.6m at 09:15 on 31/03/2025.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.6m to 7.8m at 21:00 on 30/03/2025 and 7.9m to 8.1m at 09:30 on 31/03/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 31/03/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 6.30pm and 9pm today,  Sunday 30/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9:00pm Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding is possible around the high tide from 00:45 BST on 31/03/2025.
Areas most at risk include coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve tomorrow and no further flooding is expected.
Our operations teams are closing flood gates.  Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Dover of 3.93 mAODN at 00:45 BST on 31/03/2025, which is 0.48 m above tide tables, with northerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
We will remove this message by 9:00 AM on 31/03/2025.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Barton Upon Humber to Humberston

floodArea.county: Lincolnshire, North East Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire

items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday evening. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the South Humber Bank from Barton on Humber to Humberstone. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:15 on 30 March 2025, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday evening. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along The South Humber Bank, between Whitton and South Ferriby. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:15 on 30 March 2025, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of this. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash may cause localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. If conditions deteriorate, the A1077 flood gate across the A1077 may be closed. A further message will be issued if this becomes apparent. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isnt likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads, as sea spray and waves can be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Eccles on Sea, to and including, Winterton-on-Sea
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7:00pm and 9:00pm today, Sunday 30th March. High tides mean that flood gates will be closed, restricting normal access to beaches around Eccles on Sea, and Sea Palling. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.24 mAODN at 8:00pm, on Sunday 30th March, which is 0.53m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 31st March.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary at Hessle Haven
items.message:
High tides and strong winds are expecting to cause flooding today, Sunday 30/03/25 between 6:45 PM and 8:45 PM today, Sunday 30/03/2025. 

Flooding is expected to affect areas around Hessle foreshore including Hessle Haven. Hessle foreshore flood gates are closed. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9:00PM Sunday 30/03/25.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9:00PM PM on Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

This message will be updated by 9:00PM on Sunday 30/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from the Thames Barrier to Putney Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: City of London, Greater London, Greenwich, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Wandsworth, Westminster

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.68 mAOD at 15:30 on 30/03/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 53 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 30/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight between 12:30am and 2:30am on Monday 31st March. Tide levels will be high at Battlesbrigde, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.01mAODN at 1:30am, on Monday 31st March, which is 0.37m above tide tables, wind force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am, Monday 31st March.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: Please note this Alert refers to tides on Sunday 30/03/2025, not Saturday. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected. Highest tide levels are forecast between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 8:15 AM and 8:45 PM on 30/03/2025. Flooding is possible for an hour either side of these times. The area most at risk is the coastline at Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Be careful along coastal areas such as paths and low lying roads. The detailed tidal forecast is based on the peak level at Hinkley Point. The first forecast high water is at 8:15 AM on 30/03/2025 with a level of 6.63 mAODN and north-westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 8:45 PM on 30/03/2025 with a level of 6.50 mAODN and north-westerly force 4 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level. There may be further tides that require this flood alert. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes. All times are British Summer Time.

items.description: North Sea and River Esk at Whitby Harbour
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions are expected to cause flooding Today. Flooding is expected on Sunday 30/03/2025, between 4:00 PM- 6:45 PM. 

The Whitby Harbour areas are most at risk, including Abraham's Quay, Pier Road, New Quay Road, Church Street, Campion Dock and Bagdale Road. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. 

This message will be updated by 9:00PM on Sunday 30/12/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high, but are falling slowly, on the Winterbourne Stream and the River Lambourn due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Bagnor area. The beginning of the week is expected to be mainly dry, with some bands of rain and isolated showers possible towards the end of the week. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. Levels will be sensitive to further rainfall.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are slowly falling, but remain over the flood alert thresholds. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. There is no significant rainfall forecast this week. We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 02/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels, in the Candovers and Old Alresford, are high but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 8cm. At Old Alresford, the level has fallen by 10cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall and flooding impacts will decrease. Flood impacts are expected to continue well into April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high, but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level has fallen by 19cm. We expect much of the village to experiencing cellar flooding and impacts to the sewerage system. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall and flooding impacts will decrease. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels, in the villages surrounding Andover, are high but slowly falling. At Clanville, the level has fallen by 21cm in the last week. Cellar flooding impacts may be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden and Penton Grafton. Groundwater is likely to be affecting Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton as well as the main road into Penton Grafton. Impacts to the sewerage system in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. If the weather forecast is favourable next week, this Flood Alert will be removed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high, but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Oakley, has fallen by 13cm. In Deane, we expect cellar flooding impacts to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into April. We continue to monitor the level and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram. This is due to persistent rainfall in December and January which has led to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly, at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Areas near the tidal River Welland, tidal River Nene, and the Wash

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, River Nene, The Wash

items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday evening. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the tidal River Welland, tidal River Nene and the Wash. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:30 on 30 March 2025, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday evening. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the Lincolnshire Coast. The time and date of the forecast high water is 18:45 on 30 March 2025, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Precautionary Evacuation Notice area at Snettisham seafront
items.message: High spring tides combined with a tidal surge will result in higher tide levels than usual between 19:45 and 21:45 this evening, 30/03/2025. Areas most at risk are properties in front of the flood defences, along the sea front at Snettisham. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.32mAODN at 19:45 on Sunday 30 March, which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Monday at 08:45am is currently forecast to below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10.30pm this evening, Sunday 30 March.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast at Salthouse and east Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 6:45pm and 8:45pm today, Sunday 30th March. Areas most at risk are Coast Road in Salthouse, and Coast Road in Cley. Flooding is also expected for Salthouse and Cley marshes. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Wells of 3.99 mAODN at 7:45pm, on Sunday 30th March, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 31st March.

items.description: Precautionary Evacuation Notice area at Hunstanton
items.message: High spring tides combined with a tidal surge will result in higher tide levels than usual between 19:45 and 21:45 this evening, 30/03/2025. Areas most at risk are South Beach Road, Seagate Road and the seafront at Hunstanton. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 5.32mAODN at 19:45 on Sunday 30 March, which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Monday at 08:45am is currently forecast to below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10.30pm this evening, Sunday 30 March.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast at Wells Quay
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 6:45pm and 8:45pm today, Sunday 30th March. Areas most at risk are The Quay, East End, and roads joining the Quay between the Flood Barrier and East End including, Unns Yard, Jicklings Yard, Staithe Street, Croft Yard and Standard Street. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Wells of 3.99 mAODN at 7:45pm, on Sunday 30th March, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 31st March.

items.description: Coast at St Margaret's at Cliffe, Dover, Folkestone and Sandgate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding overnight.
Flooding is expected around the high tide of 00:45 BST on 31/03/2025.
Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths but some low lying properties near to the seafront may also be impacted.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve tomorrow and no further flooding is expected.
We are closing flood gates.  Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.  Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Dover of 3.93mAODN at 00:45 (BST) on 31/03/2025, which is 0.48m above tide tables, with northerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
We will remove this message by 09:00 BST on 31/03/2025.

items.description: Bosham and West Itchenor
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 31/03/2025 is higher than normal, with light North Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.21 m. The total forecast tide is 5.40 metres Chart Datum (2.66 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, flooding will affect Shore Road and a small number of properties in Bosham High Street and Gloucester Terrace. Water will reach the top of slipways in West Itchenor. Monday afternoon's tide at 13:45 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be 40 cm lower (2.26 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected Monday afternoon, or through next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 31/03/2025.
